entry.title: Craftsmanship Analogy
entry.content:
I’ve found this set of tweets about the craftsmanship analogy by Sarah Mei:

Just put my finger on why the craft/workshop metaphor for software development doesn't quite fit.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

"Craft" doesn't build any collaboration into the process, except in a top-down control-oriented way (master, journeyman, apprentice).

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

"Craft" casts software development as an individual achievement, just as in a workshop, the master did all the important work on each piece.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

Software development is sometimes like that. But the craft/workshop metaphor doesn't fit at all with what modern small teams do.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

Modeling development as a "craft" means hoarding information rather than sharing openly, & individual rather than collective code ownership.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

Craft means teams have a rigid hierarchy in which folks at the lowest levels just watch the higher-ups work, rather than participating.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 25, 2015

The folks who like the craft metaphor tend to use it to mean "we take pride in our work." I don't dispute that that is important.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

But the craft metaphor has other implications, some of which, historically, were more important to a shop than "taking time to do it right."

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

Some people want the information hoarding & rigid hierarchy that go along with "craft." But some of the folks who use it surely don't.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

It's unfortunate they chose "craft" & built companies & conferences around a metaphor that is such a remarkably poor fit for a modern team.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

Software as craft was a reaction to the growing popularity of the factory model, in which developers are replaceable line workers.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

Both the factory and the craft metaphors, while they each describe some software orgs, don't describe any sort of team I want to be on.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

Or any sort of team I *have* been on, in the last 15 years.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

I should say, any of the teams I have enjoyed being on. The teams I didn't enjoy had some element of either the workshop or the factory.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

It's time for us to move on from "craft." To what, though?

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

I've been thinking about "stage," in which team members are part of an ensemble cast working together to form a creative work.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

"Stage" does allow for a single person (perhaps a big name) to come in & ruin the collaboration by making it all about them. :D

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

In broad strokes, the acting ensemble metaphor does describe the teams I've loved working on better than craft/workshop or factory.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

The seed of this idea came from Artful Making's descriptions of how a director & actors put together a play.

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

I don't have first-hand experience to draw on. But I suppose none of the software-as-craft folks have apprenticed at a blacksmith, either.üòä

— Sarah Mei (@sarahmei) July 26, 2015

Some notes:

  • “type systems […] language feature used to reduce bugs”
  • two types: Church’s typed Œª-calculi and Martin-L√∂f’s intuitionistic type theory.
  • notation:
    • typing judgement: M : A. Term M has type A
    • example: nat may be a type
    • 2 : nat, like in Scala
    • function: “arrow”
    • apply function to argument: no parenthesis
  • conversion rule: rule for rewriting terms
    • reduction rule: conversion rule that only works in one direction
  • normal form: a form that cannot be further reduced
  • element: all closed elements that can be reduced to the same normal form
  • closed term: a term without parameters. Opposite is an open term
  • convertibility: property of terms, both open and closed. Said to be convertible if two terms can be reduced to the same term

  • Classification of types:

    • class ‚Äì a type of an object
    • kind ‚Äì a type of a type, or metatype
  • the type inference might be undecidable (for more complex type inference)
  • “Strong typing offers more safety, but cannot guarantee complete type safety.” An example is the division by zero, altough some languages may declare a dependent type “non-zero numbers”

entry.title: The Guardian of the Source
entry.content:
Overheard today at the office, while they were discussing the approval of a pull request:

[Pull request reviewer] - I’m sorry, can’t approve this: I don’t really agree with this design. Isn’t there an alternative for this?

[Pull request author] - [redacted], of course you don’t, you’re the guardian of the source

[PR reviewer] - Well, sometimes I’m a bit picky about introducing bad code into our codebase.

This has made me think about Gandalf blocking the path of Balrog Demon, shouting “you shall not pass” while on top of the bridge.

This is part of the objectives of doing a pull request before merging code: stop the bad code1 before it is merged to the codebase.

Later, as you start having broken windows in your codebase, it is easier that you start introducing more. Exactly about this is the broken windows theory.

On the other hand, if you try to block that bad code before it is merged, it is cheaper to remove it: nothing depends on it, you introduce no repetition, etc2

This also connects with the idea present in Software Craftsmanship, now called The Software Craftsman, about preserving value for investors and treat software as an investment (with positive ROI) rather than a sunk cost.

It is being picky and, to the most of our possibilities, do not letting any defects nor bad code into the codebase. A hedge fund manager would not let any toxic or dubious asset into the managed funds. This would be counterproductive in the long run (maybe even in the short one) and would be not doing their job correctly. Why is it that some developers suggest or accept these toxic assets?

So, at least for me, would be an honor to be called the “Guardian of the Source” by someone I respect, as long as this is a serious proposition (i.e., not a joke of some kind).

  1. Bad code can be expressed in many ways: long methods, bad naming, breaking design principles (e.g., SOLID, KISS, DRY - OAOO), code with defects, no tests or no coverage, etc.↩

  2. A source is Discover defects early. Another is this paper that cites the ratio of fixing it later to 5:1 (five times more expensive).↩
